description: Borrowed from French contour, from contourner, equivalent to con- +â€Ž tour.

entries.meaning: An outline, boundary or border, usually of curved shape.
examples: the low drag contour of a modern automobile

entries.meaning: A line on a map or chart delineating those points which have the same altitude or other plotted quantity: a contour line or isopleth.
(linguistics) a speech sound which behaves as a single segment, but which makes an internal transition from one quality, place, or manner to another.
(figurative) A general description giving the most important points.

verbs.description: contour (third-person singular simple present contours, present participle contouring, simple past and past participle contoured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form a more or less curved boundary or border upon.
(intransitive) To practise the makeup technique of contouring.
